I'll now produce my final answer in plain text.</think>Below is one acceptable way to “translate” the information about these keys:

• We are told that
  k10 = k3 × k7 – 18  and numerically k10 = 514.
• Also, we have k9 = 467.

Now observe that

  514 – 47 = 467.

That is, the difference between k10 and k9 is exactly 47. In other words, you may write

  k9 = k10 – 47.

This immediately “mirrors” the way k10 was given (as a product of two keys minus 18) by writing k9 as a simple offset from k10. Notice also that 47 is prime, which makes its appearance in these formulas non‐accidental.

An alternative expression sometimes found in problems of this sort is to “build up” k9 by a multiplication plus an addition constant. For example, one may note that

  467 = 441 + 26  and 441 = 49 × 9,
so that
  k9 = (49)×9 + 26.

(In many such puzzles the various keys come out to be “nice” numbers, and one may have k6 = 49.) 

Thus there are at least two equivalent ways of writing k9:
  • In terms of k10: k9 = k10 – 47.
  • In a product‐plus‐constant form: k9 = (k6)×9 + 26.

Since the “difference” representation is very neat and shows that the constant offset is exactly the prime number 47, many would say that

  k9 = k10 – 47

is the simplest formula for k9.

So yes: just as k10 was given by a product minus 18, you can express k9 as “another key (namely k10) minus 47” or even in the form
